Shape.Name: Sheet.104
Shape.Text: Handles control template conversion for render of browser control html. This class has the default render method for all the nitobi controls via templates. Child classes can help control the browser html rendering process via virtual methods.

Shape.Name: Sheet.108
Shape.Text: Handles the generic processing of columns and contains the column related properties.

Shape.Name: Sheet.115
Shape.Text: Each Nitobi control is handled by an individual class that deals with the specific issues related to that control.

Shape.Name: Sheet.111
Shape.Text: Handles generating data source into compressed xml for controls doing ajax get/put data calls. Can be used by an ASPX to handle the call without creating the control. Can also be used by the control when it is embedding the data in its html to the browser. End user apps can build classes to inherit from this that will be able to control the generation of the compressed XML.

Shape.Name: Sheet.126
Shape.Text: This package contains all of the .NET classes needed to map up to the inner contents of the Nitobi Server controls like the Tree, Grid and Combo. This includes inner contents such as the Grid column definition and the Combo textbox definition. These make life easier for the programmer by making Visual Studio intellisense work in html edit mode. There is one class in this package per unique inner element type.

Shape.Name: Sheet.148
Shape.Text: This element provides the actual data that is used by the XmlDataHandler to product the compressedXml. Fore each datasource the XmlDataHandler will have there needs to be an instance of this interface. XmlDataHandler is prepared to get any implementation of this interface, making it easy for an end user developer to write a customer data provider to do anything they need to get the data.

Shape.Name: Sheet.175
Shape.Text: A simple ASP.NET control that will render an XML data island based on its given data source. Currently only renders one list of data and is usable only by the Combo

Shape.Name: Sheet.67
Shape.Text:
Scenario 1: Ajax get/save data requests go back to original page. All the form data is sent back so that the controls on the page are able to be created and have their state setup properly. The XmlDataHandler is used by the Page to process the request and response to the client. The page will have the AjaxGetData and/or AjaxSaveData handlers embedded within it which will be able to properly access any other form fields as needed to get the data properly. Because the grid is on the page, the XmlDataHandler can also easily get the list of columns it needs to properly create the compressed xml response. This approach is not the fastest option because all of the controls on the page are being created even if they don’t play a part in processing the ajax request. It is also going to be slower because more bytes are being sent up to the web server for form data, including view state. In this scenario, the impact of an ajax request is nearly the same as a normal full page postback.
NOTE: This scenario will not work with the Nitobi javascript code base as is. The grid only uses the HTTP GET method for ajax calls. The combo can do posts and even tries to send the view state form data, it doesn’t do it properly and its not robust enough for this.

Shape.Name: Sheet.68
Shape.Text: Scenario 2: Ajax get/save data requests go to a different url, which may even be a completely different server from the original page. The form data sent is only that which is needed (column definitions plus whatever else is added by the end user’s code). The handler page has no ASP.NET controls in it. The scenario will use less server resources and process faster than scenario 1 because it wont have to do full page processing (minus the render of the page) on ajax get/save data calls. The size of the data going up to the server in the ajax request will be smaller, which will also decrease the time it takes to process the ajax event.
